Finding the JUnit Platform bundles -

Alternatively, it is not difficult to download the required (non-OSGi) modules from Maven Central and include them as-is on -runpath, or else (preferably) wrap them into bundles and include them in -runrequires/-runbundles.

+

Alternatively, it is not difficult to download the required (non-OSGi) modules from Maven Central and include them as-is on -runpath, or else (preferably) wrap them into bundles and include them in -runrequires/-runbundles. As of JUnit 5.6, the JUnit jars already have the OSGi metadata and so can be used as bundles direct from Maven Central.

+ +

Also note that unfortunately, due to a bug in biz.aQute.tester.junit-platform, Bndtools 5.0 does not work with JUnit 5.5+. This has already been fixed in the main development branch and we expect the fix to be included in Bndtools 5.0.1 (to be released soon).

timeline.message:
[docs] Update/correct tester docs with latest version information

-Old docs referred to 4.4 release which became the 5.0 release.
-Old docs referred to Eclipse Oxygen, which is now Eclipse 2018-12.
-Added note about 5.6 release of JUnit being bundled.
-Added note about incompatibility with JUnit 5.5.

Signed-off-by: Fr Jeremy Krieg <fr.jkrieg@greekwelfaresa.org.au>
